{{Infobox musical composition | name = O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness | type = | image = Censored page of O'er The Gloomy Hills of Darkness in Church Hymnal, 1877.jpg|thumb|O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness in the [[Anglican Church of Canada|Church of England in Canada]]'s 1877 Church Hymnal | alt = | caption = | translation = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | composer = | genre = [[Hymn]] | occasion = | text = [[William Williams Pantycelyn]] | language = | written = 1772 | based_on = {{Sourcetext|source=Bible|version=King James|book=Isaiah|chapter=9|verse=2}} | meter = 8.7.8.7.4.7 | melody = "Regent Square" by [[Henry Smart]], "Zion" by [[Thomas Hastings (composer)|Thomas Hastings]] | composed = | published = | misc = }} "'''O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness'''", also titled "'''O'er Those Gloomy Hills of Darkness'''",{{cite book | first =John| last =Kirk| title =Cultures of Radicalism in Britain and Ireland | publisher = Routledge| year = 2013| isbn =1848933444|page=100}} is a Welsh Christian hymn by [[William Williams Pantycelyn]] written in 1772.{{cite book | first =Saunders| last =Lewis| title =Williams Pantycelyn | publisher = Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru| year = 1991 | isbn =0708311229 |page=128}} The hymn was written as a missionary hymn; there are conflicting accounts of why the hymn was written. The hymn was later published in 374 hymnals worldwide,{{cite web|url=http://www.hymnary.org/text/oer_the_gloomy_hills_of_darkness |title=O'er the gloomy hills of darkness |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2016-06-14}} though it was censored and altered in the United States by slaveholders for evangelising to slaves. The hymn later fell out of favour with hymn book editors in the 1960s. == History == There are conflicting accounts of why the hymn was written. According to one account, [[George Bowen (missionary)|George Bowen]] was converted to Christianity through hearing a Welsh girl singing hymns. He later went to stay at Llwyn-Gwair Manor at the same time that the [[Welsh Methodist Association]] were there. While there, he met Williams and asked him to compose some verse about the [[Preseli Hills]]. "O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness" was written as a result of these requests. Though it is possible that this story may be correct as Llwyn-Gwair Manor and Williams' bedroom at the manor did overlook [[Carn Igli]], in the 19th century an alternative story arose. In this version, Williams was travelling to [[Pontrhydyfen]] and composing a new missionary hymn as part of a commission from [[Selina Hastings, Countess of Huntingdon]]. Upon passing the ruins of an old [[Cistercian]] abbey and seeing the mountains he would have to cross on a stormy night, the view inspired him to write "O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness" for the Countess.Kirk, 100 The hymn was first written in Welsh as English was not Williams' first language so it was later translated into English by another person. This was because Williams did not know enough English to fully express the intent of the original Welsh verses in translation.{{cite book | first1 =John | last1 =Mason | first2 =Thomas | last2 =Shepherd | title = Spiritual Songs, or Songs of Praise to Almighty God: upon several occasions | publisher = D. Sedgwick | edition = | year = 1859 | page=2}} In 1836, "O'er the Gloomy hills of Darkness" was reviewed in an issue of ''[[The Eclectic Review]]''. In a remarkably snide review, the hymn, among many others, is criticised for a lack of grammatical correctness as well as a lack of rhyme in the first verse, " ...inane verbiage preferred by worthy people to the noblest compositions of sanctified genius; and to blot it out from our hymn-books would be a species of sacrilege".{{cite journal |last= Allen|first= William|date= October 1836|title= Psalms and Hymns for Public Worship|journal= The Eclectic Review |volume= 16|issue= |pages=288 |doi= }} This was attributed to Williams' lack of English as a native language gave rise to "a stiffness apparent" in the hymn.{{cite book | first =Thomas | last =Olivers |authorlink=Thomas Olivers | title = Hymns, and an Elegy on the death of John Wesley; reprinted from the originals. With a biographical sketch of the author by J. Kirk. | publisher = D. Sedgwick; Hamilton, Adams, and Co. | edition = reprint | year = 1868 |page=5}} The [[New York Times]] stated it had gained popularity because of Williams' "ease and sweetness" in his hymn writing.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1853/11/26/archives/religious-history-chronicles-of-religious-seets-in-the-united.html|title=No. II.-Welsh Calvanistic Methodists.|date=1853-11-26|publisher=New York Times |accessdate=2016-06-08|subscription=yes|via=NYTimes.com}} == Controversy == The second verse of the hymn begins with the lines "Let the Indian, let the negro, Let the rude barbarian see". Williams included this after hearing stories of promising missionary contact with [[Cherokee]] tribes and with slaves in the [[Province of Georgia]].Kirk, 108 When the hymn became established in the United States, slave owners changed the line referencing "Indian" and "negro" to "Let the dark benighted pagan". The abolitionist Ebenezer Davies claimed “The altered reading, I learned, prevails universally in America, except in the original version used by the Welsh congregations. Slave-holders, and the abettors of that horrid system which makes it a crime to teach a negro to read the Word of God, felt perhaps that they could not devoutly and consistently sing "Let the Indian, let the negro ... see”.{{cite book | first =Ebenezer | last =Davies | title =American Scenes and Christian Slavery: A Recent Tour of Four Thousand Miles in the United States | publisher = J. Snow | edition = 1 | year = 1849 | page = 150}} In the 1850s, the [[Baptists Together|Baptist Union of Great Britain]] dropped the hymn from usage. The reason published in the ''[[Baptist Magazine]]'' stated "But the verses are too rude and unfinished to be generally accepted in modern day". In later years in the 19th century churches, including the [[Church of England]], started to publish the hymn replacing the second verse with the American slave owner's amended version.{{cite web|url=http://www.hymnary.org/hymn/CH1886/260 |title=Church Hymnal 260. O'er the gloomy hills of darkness |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} In the early 1900s, the second verse would often be omitted altogether from hymnals.{{cite web|url=http://www.hymnary.org/hymn/MHTB1917/page/314 |title=Methodist Hymn and Tune Book: official hymn book of the Methodist Church page 314 |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} == Hymnals == "O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness" first appeared in published [[hymnals]] in 1792.{{cite book | first =Saunders| last =Lewis| title =Williams Pantycelyn | publisher = Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru| year = 1991 | isbn =0708311229 |page=128}} [[Jeffrey Richards]] states that "William Williams's ''O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness'' of 1772 (sung variously to [[Thomas Clark (composer)|Thomas Clark's]] ''Calcutta'', by [[Baptists]]; to [[Henry Gauntlett| Henry Gauntlett's]] ''Triumph'', in ''[[The Scottish Hymnal]]''; to [[Edwin Moss's]] ''Ulpha'', in the 1982 ''[[Presbyterian Church Praise]]'') did not make it into ''[[Hymns Ancient and Modern]]'', but it was in [[Edward Bickersteth (priest) |Bickersteth's]] ''[[Christian Psalmody]]'' in 1833 and was still to be found complete in the 1933 [[Baptist Hymnal]] … This very much set the tone for missionary hymns."{{cite book | first =Jeffrey | last =Richards | title =Imperialism and Music: Britain 1876–1953 | publisher = Manchester University Press | edition = | year = 2001 | isbn = 0719061431 |page=388}} After being published in 374 hymnals throughout history, in the 1960s the hymn stopped being published in all Christian hymnals.{{cite web|url=http://www.hymnary.org/text/oer_the_gloomy_hills_of_darkness |title=O'er the gloomy hills of darkness |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2016-04-30}} The [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]] retained the hymn in their hymnals from 1927 until dropping it in 1985. This was because its members in modern times felt that the hymn connected [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and black people with barbarians.{{cite paper |first=Douglas |last=Campbell |title=Changes in LDS hymns: Implications and Opportunities |url=https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V28N03_79.pdf |publisher=[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought|Dialogue]] |accessdate=2016-06-08}} The hymn's lyrical style set the tone for future missionary hymns. "O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness" inspired the founder of [[Methodism]], [[Charles Wesley]], to write "Sun of Unclouded Righteousness" for missionaries working with "Mahometans". == Lyrics == The lyrics of "O'er the Gloomy Hills of Darkness" as published in ''Gloria in Excelsis: or hymns of praise to God and the lamb'' in 1772.{{cite book | first =William| last =Williams| title =Gloria in Excelsis: or hymns of praise to God and the lamb | publisher = J. Ross| year = 1772| pages=33-34}}
1. :O'er those gloomy Hills of Darkness :Look my Soul, be still and gaze, :All the Promises do travel :On a glorious Day of Grace, :Blessed Jubil, ''& c.'' :Let thy glorious Morning dawn. 2. :Let the Indian, let the Negro, :Let the rude Barbarian see :That divine and glorious Conquest :Once obtain'd on ''Calvary''; :Let the Gospel, ''& c.'' :Word resound from Pole to Pole. 3. :Kingdoms wide that sit in Darkness, :Let them have the glorious Light, :And from Eastern Coast to Western :May the Morning chase the Night, :And Redemption, ''& c.'' :Freely purchas'd win the Day. 4. :May the glorious Days approaching, :From eternal Darkness dawn, :And the everlasting Gospel :Spread abroad thy holy Name. :Thousand Years, ''& c.'' :Soon appear, make no Delay. 5. :Lord, I long to see that Morning, :When thy Gospel shall abound, :And thy Grace get full Possession :Of the happy promis'd Ground; :All the Borders, ''& c.'' :Of the great Immanuel's Land. 6. :Fly abroad, eternal Gospel, :Win and conquer, never cease; :May thy eternal wide Dominions :Multiply, and still increase; :May thy Scepter, ''& c.'' :Sway th'enlight'ned World around. 7. :O let Moab yield and tremble, :Let Philistia never boast, :And let India proud be scatt'red :With their numerable Host; :And the Glory, ''&c.'' :Jesus only be to thee.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Bibliography == *{{cite book | first =John Gwilym| last =Jones| title =William Williams, Pantycelyn | publisher = Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru| year = 1969 | isbn =090076807X}} *{{cite book | first =Saunders| last =Lewis| title =Williams Pantycelyn | publisher = Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru| year = 1991 | isbn =0708311229 }} *{{cite book | first =John (editor)| last =Kirk | title =Cultures of Radicalism in Britain and Ireland | publisher = Routledge | edition = | year = 2013 | isbn = 1317320654 }} == External links == *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iOztpqRc7RY A 1964 recording of the hymn in Westminster Chapel] {{Good article}} [[Category:Welsh Christian hymns]] [[Category:Christianity and slavery]] [[Category:Missional Christianity]] [[Category:1772 songs]] [[Category:Protestant hymns]]

[http://www.alqudsalarabi.info/index.asp?fname=today%5C27qpt478.htm&arc=data%5C2012%5C06%5C06-27%5C27qpt478.htm "المقاومة المدنية والدولة الديموقراطية"], ''[[civil society activist]]'', alqudsalarabi,london , 27 Jun 2012. Retrieved on 27 Jun 2012.</ref> He later moved to [[Egypt]] to pursue higher education, during which time the Tunisian revolution started.{{Citation needed|date=February 2015}}
The first role that Osama took on as a revolutionary was that of a media activist. Gradually, however, he transitioned over to the political realm.<ref>wanted names , osama alsamman. [http://www.aljazeera.net/file/Get/9ff38110-d3dc-430c-ba19-331a504d1c38 "Wanted the names of the Syrian regime"], ''[[Wanted the names of the Syrian regime]]'', Aljazeera, Syria, 2013. Retrieved in 2013.</ref>
==Contributions to the Syrian uprising== Osama’s revolutionary activities commenced after the Syrian [[Arab spring|Day of Rage]], February 5, 2011, when he began producing protest videos.Osama also worked as a media spokesperson for the city of al-Tal. Additionally.
Moreover, Osama was actively involved in various media campaigns that sought to shed light on the plight of Syrian prisoners of consciousness. The most prominent campaign he participated in was that for blogger [[Razan Ghazzawi|RazanGhazzawi]], which received the 2012 BOBs Award for the Best Social Activism Campaign.<ref>BOBs Award , razan . [http://www.dw.de/bobs-2012-they-cant-stop-me/a-16051809 "Best Social Activism Campaign"], ''[[2012 BOBs Award]]'', dw, Germany , 26 jun 2012. Retrieved on 26 jun 2012.</ref>
When Suheir Attasi, a member of SRGU, was appointed to the Syrian National Coalition [[:ar:الائتلاف الوطني لقوى الثورة والمعارضة السورية|the Syrian National Coalition]], SRGU subsequently appointed Osama to manage her presidential office.<ref>Syrian National Coalition, osama alsamman SRGU. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8NusZVIYb1U&list=PL906Y6OrlAXi0iv1L_FTsas8Eswh8CI7k " Syria 2020 "], ''[[youtube.com Syria 2020,Syrian National Coalition ]]'', televisionOrient , Syria , 23 jun 2013. Retrieved on 23 jun 2013.</ref> It is also notable to mention that Osama was among the eighteen individuals who represented the Syrian opposition at the 2013 [[Arab League]] summit, where the opposition was granted the Arab League seat. He also participated in the founding conference of the Syrian Democratic Union, where he was elected as a member of its secretariat.
Moreover, Osama was actively involved in various media campaigns that sought to shed light on the plight of Syrian prisoners of consciousness. The most prominent campaign he participated in was that for blogger Razan Ghazzawi, which received the 2012 BOBs Award for the Best Social Activism Campaign.<ref>BOBs Award , razan . [http://www.dw.de/bobs-2012-they-cant-stop-me/a-16051809 "Best Social Activism Campaign"], ''[[2012 BOBs Award]]'', dw, Germany , 26 jun 2012. Retrieved on 26 jun 2012.</ref>

[[File:Ottofbranstetter.jpg|thumb|right|Otto F. Branstetter]]'''Otto Franklin Branstetter''' (1877-1924) was an American socialist official.<ref>Branstetter listed his occupation as "political work" and his employer as "Socialist Party" on his World War 1 Draft Registration Card dated September 7, 1918, Chicago Draft Board</ref> Branstetter served as executive secretary of National Executive Committee of the [[Socialist Party of America]] from 1919 until shortly before his death in 1924.<ref name="Ross2015">{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Jack|title=The Socialist Party of America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fud1BwAAQBAJ|accessdate=14 March 2016|date=2015-04-15|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=9781612347509|page=603}}</ref>
Branstetter was a private in Company G, 3rd Missouri Infantry in the [[Spanish–American War]] in 1898.<ref>''U.S., Spanish American War Volunteers Index to Compiled Military Service Records, 1898'' Ancestry.com, 2012</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=G8EaAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA1497&lpg=PA1497&dq=Otto+Franklin+Branstetter&source=bl&ots=8hsI0A-f3B&sig=8tf17HXyKvy-jzgcv4b4tw22C2w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8gfrcts3VAhVG5GMKHch2AU0Q6AEINjAD#v=onepage&q=Otto%20Franklin%20Branstetter&f=false New York Legislative Documents, Volume 12, Page 1497, 1920]</ref>
In 1921, Branstetter was a prominent founding member of the secular Jewish [[Yiddish]]-oriented political organization, the [[Jewish Socialist Verband]].<ref name="NYT 1921">{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Jewish Socialists Split: Faction Loyal to National Party Organizes Verband | newspaper = New York Times | pages = | year = | date = 6 September 1921 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/09/06/109822335.pdf | accessdate = 14 March 2016| format=PDF}}</ref> In 1921, Branstetter was a lead organizer against the communist-affiliated left wing within the Socialist Party when he introduced a resolution that called for the expulsion of SPA members who supported the [[Communist International]] (comintern). On February 1, 1924, Branstetter submitted his resignation to the National Executive Committee, calling himself tired and worn out,". He was replaced by his assistant, [[Bertha Hale White]].
Otto and his wife, [[Winnie Branstetter]], married in 1899 and moved to [[Oklahoma]] in 1904. They had two children, Gertrude and Theresa. Otto's wife, Winnie, was also a socialist organizer as well as a prominent [[suffragette]]. She died in Providence, Rhode Island on November 15, 1960.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=BR007|title=Branstetter, Winnie Estelle Shirley|publisher=Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture|accessdate=14 March 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Paul O. Williams reading from his book of cat haiku at the Yuki Teikei Holiday Party 2006.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Paul O. Williams reading from his book of cat haiku.]] '''Paul O. Williams''' (January 17, 1935 – June 2, 2009) was an American [[science fiction]] writer and [[haiku]] poet. Williams was professor emeritus of English at [[Principia College]] in [[Elsah, Illinois]].
His most notable science fiction works are a series of novels, the Pelbar Cycle, set in [[North America]] about a thousand years after a "time of fire", in which the world was nearly totally depopulated. The novels track a gradual reconnection of the human cultures which developed. Much of the action takes place in the communities of the Pelbar, along the [[Upper Mississippi River]] — in the general vicinity of Elsah. Several cultures, including the matriarchal Pelbar, join together in the Heart River Federation. Others, especially the tyrannical Tantal and slave-raiding Tusco, fall apart after suffering defeats. The predominant characters are change agents: Tor, Jestak, Stel and his wife Ahroe Westrun. All are Pelbar except for Tor who is Shumai. Williams won the [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer|John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer in Science Fiction]] in 1983.<ref name="nyt830906"/>
He is also known as a writer of [[haiku]], [[senryū]], and [[Tanka in English|tanka]], and wrote a number of essays on the haiku form in English. In a 1975 essay, he coined the term "Tontoism" to refer to the practice of writing haiku with missing [[Article (grammar)|articles]] ("the", "a", or "an"), which he claimed made the haiku sound like the stunted English of the Indian sidekick, [[Tonto (Lone Ranger character)|Tonto]], in the ''[[Lone Ranger]]'' radio and television series. In 2001, his best essays were collected in ''The Nick of Time: Essays on Haiku Aesthetics'', edited by Lee Gurga and Michael Dylan Welch. Williams was the president of the [[Haiku Society of America]] (1999) and vice president of the Tanka Society of America (2000). In 1989 he won the Museum of Haiku Literature Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsa-haiku.org/museumhaikuliteratureawards/museumhaikuliterature-award.htm#1989|title=Museum of Haiku Literature Award}}</ref> from the Haiku Society of America with this poem written for Nick Virgilio shortly after Nick's death:
{{quote|<poem> gone from the woods the bird I knew by song alone </poem>}}
Williams died from an [[aortic dissection]] on June 2, 2009.<ref name="sfwa09"/>

{{hatnote|Pinching is a [[Multi-touch#Multi-touch gestures|multi-touch]] gesture, done by squeezing one's fingers on a [[touchscreen]].}}
A '''pinch''' is a grip of a flexible object in which a portion is taken between two [[finger]]s, until it hurts, or something of resemblance and squeezed so the gripped portion of the object is lifted from its normal level. By extension, that which is taken in the grip is referred to as a "pinch."
When the fingers are used to perform a pinch, the action usually consists of the [[thumb]] and one other finger. The closer to the thumb the other finger is located, the stronger the pinch.
==Pinch of the skin== The term "pinch" often refers to the action being taken on the [[skin]]. A pinch of the skin displaces the skin and [[blood]] beneath from its natural position, and may inflict a minor degree of pain, which may increase if the amount of skin being pinched is smaller, but is usually tolerable to most.
Pinching the skin can result in [[pinch mark]]s, a [[List of cutaneous conditions|cutaneous condition]], and when on the ears or in the genital region of male children may be suggestive of child abuse.<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book |author=Rapini, Ronald P. |author2=Bolognia, Jean L. |author3=Jorizzo, Joseph L. |title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set |publisher=Mosby |location=St. Louis |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=1-4160-2999-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===Medical uses=== [[File:Penile nerve block dorsal.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The skin is being pinched while an injection is being given]] Pinching has the following uses in health care and medicine: *The skin is often pinched prior to giving an [[injection (medicine)|injection]] in order to get the needle in the desired location. *In [[neurology]], pinching can be used to determine pain sensitivity for a certain area of skin. *Can be used to determine [[Resilience (materials science)|resiliency]] in the skin of an [[old age|aged person]]. When the skin is pinched, the amount of time the pinch remains visible following the pinch is an indicator.<ref>Physical dimensions of aging By Waneen Wyrick Spirduso, Karen L. Francis, Priscilla G. MacRae: Page 83</ref> *When skin has been [[sunburn|damaged by the sun]], pinching can be used to determine the amount of damage. Examining the appearance with varying amounts of time following the pinch can be used to determine the amount of damage.<ref>Photodamaged skin: clinical signs, causes and management By Jean-Paul Ortonne, Ronald Marks: Page 19</ref> *In determining [[dehydration]], pinching the skin can serve as a test. The speed at which the pinch turns back can help determine the level of dehydration. The slower it goes back, the more severe the dehydration.<ref>Handbook IMCI: integrated management of childhood illness By World Health Organization. Dept. of Child and Adolescent Health and Development: Page 27</ref> *[[Body fat percentage]] can be determined the [[skinfold test]], in which a pinch of skin is precisely measured by calipers at several standardized points on the body to determine the subcutaneous fat layer thickness. These measurements are converted to an estimated body fat percentage by an equation. *Pinching is used as part of the diagnosis of [[schleroderma]]. In schleroderma patients, the skin between the fingers becomes too difficult to pinch.<ref>Atlas of the musculoskeletal examination By Gerald F. Moore, Gerald Moore: Page 46</ref> *In [[veterinary medicine]], small amounts of animal skin is pinched in order to perform [[Medical grafting|grafting]].<ref>Techniques in large animal surgery By Anthony Simon Turner, C. Wayne McIlwraith, Bruce L. Hull: Page 129</ref>
==Pinch of powder== A pinch can refer to the taking of a small amount of a [[powder (substance)|powdery substance]].
In cooking, a "[[Pinch (cooking)|pinch]]" refers to a small amount of an ingredient, such as [[table salt|salt]] or a [[spice]], being taken to be placed within a recipe.
Small amounts of [[street drug]]s are sometimes referred to as a "pinch."

{{Distinguish|Contemporary history}}
The term "'''present age'''" is a concept in the [[philosophy of Søren Kierkegaard]]. A formulation of the [[modern age]] can be found in [[Kierkegaard]]'s work ''[[Two Ages: A Literary Review]]'':
{{quote|Our age is essentially one of understanding and reflection, without passion, momentarily bursting into enthusiasm, and shrewdly relapsing into repose. ... There is no more action or decision in our day than there is perilous delight in swimming in shallow waters.|sign=Kierkegaard, Søren|source=''Two Ages: A Literary Review''.<ref>Kierkegaard, Søren. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CNolAQAAMAAJ&q= ''The Present Age and of the Difference Between a Genius and an Apostle''], trans. Alexander Dru (New York: Harper Torchbooks, 1940), p. 33 and 36; translation modified by [http://www.historyguide.org/europe/present_age.html historyguide.org/]</ref>}}
==Overview== Kierkegaard argues the present age drains the meaning out of [[ethical]] concepts through passionless indolence. The concepts are still used, but are drained of all meaning by virtue of their detachment from a life view which is passion-generated and produces consistent action.<ref>Lillegard, Norman. ''Thinking with Kierkegaard and MacIntyre about Virtue'', in: ''Kierkegaard after MacIntyre''.{{page needed|date=September 2014}}</ref>
Kierkegaard published this book in 1846 just after the [[Corsair Affair]] in which he was attacked by the press. He attacks not only the Press but the Public it serves in this book. He is against abstract moments in time or public opinion as a basis for forming relationships. He wrote about the single individual in his ''[[Eighteen Upbuilding Discourses]]'' and kept to that category here.
Newspapers were mediating information and individuals were joining together based on this mediating influence. The same thing is happening now with the internet. Kierkegaard advised that "real" people retain a concrete identity in the face of an abstract [[public opinion]]. He wrote: {{Quotation|More and more people renounce the quiet and modest tasks of life, that are so important and pleasing to God, in order to achieve something greater; in order to think over the relationships of life in a higher relationship till in the end the whole generation has become a representation, who represent…it is difficult to say who; and who think about these relationships…for whose sake it is not easy to discover. The real moment in time and the real situation being simultaneous with real people, each of whom is something; that is what helps to sustain the individual. But the existence of a public produces neither a situation nor simultaneity. The individual reader of the Press is not the public, and even though little by little a number of individuals or even all of them should read it, the simultaneity is lacking. Years might be spent gathering the public together, and still it would not be there. This abstraction, which the individuals so illogically form, quite rightly repulses the individual instead of coming to his help. The man who has no opinion of an event at the actual moment accepts the opinion of the majority, or, if he is quarrelsome, of the minority. But it must be remembered that both majority and minority are real people, and that is why the individual is assisted by adhering to them. A public, on the contrary, is an abstraction. Soren Kierkegaard, ''The Present Age'', (1846) Dru translation 1962 p. 44, 61}}
==Interpretations== ''The Present Age'' and ''[[Two Minor Ethical-Religious Essays|Two Minor Ethico-Religious Treatises]]'' were originally translated by [[Walter Lowrie (author)|Walter Lowrie]] and Alexander Dru in 1940. Later, in 1962, Alexander Dru's translation of ''The Present Age'' was published along with ''Of The Difference Between a Genius and an Apostle''.<ref>The second essay of the above mentioned two minor essays, the first essay was ''Has a Man the Right to Let Himself Be Put to Death for the Truth?''</ref> This translation had a long introduction by [[Walter Kaufmann (philosopher)|Walter Kaufmann]].
Several contemporary philosophers, including [[Anthony Rudd (philosopher)|Anthony Rudd]], [[John Davenport (philosopher)|John Davenport]], and [[Alasdair MacIntyre]]<ref>Davenport, John; Rudd, Anthony; and MacIntyre, Alasdair. ''Kierkegaard after MacIntyre: essays on freedom, narrative, and virtue'', 2001, pp. 226–229.</ref> allocate this concept and apply it as an analysis of [[nihilism]]. [[Hubert Dreyfus]], for example in his essay "Anonymity vrs. Commitment in the Present Age", argues that Kierkegaard, "who was always concerned with nihilism, warns that his age is characterized by a disinterested reflection and curiosity that levels all differences of status and value."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socrates.berkeley.edu/~hdreyfus/html/paper_kierkegaard.html |title=Kierkegaard on the Internet: Anonymity vrs. Commitment in the Present Age |author=Hubert L. Dreyfus |date=2004 |work= |publisher=Regents of the University of California |accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref>
Other thinkers apply the concept as a symptom of [[herd behavior]] or [[mob mentality]]. Norman Lillegard argues that the present age is "incapable of anything but 'crowd actions' which are not true actions at all."<ref>Lillegard, Norman. ''Thinking with Kierkegaard and MacIntyre about Virtue'', in: ''Kierkegaard after MacIntyre''.{{page needed|date=September 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Leveling (philosophy)|Leveling]]
==References== <references />

Sadler, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oY56_y-0RgY&feature=plcp ''Existentialism: Soren Kierkegaard, "The Present Age"''], June 5, 2012. YouTube. * [http://sorenkierkegaard.org/two-ages.html Storm's Commentary on ''The Present Age'']

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} A '''psychological punishment''' is a type of [[punishment]] that relies not or only in secondary order on the actual harm inflicted (such as [[corporal punishment]]s or fines) but on psychological effects, mainly emotions, such as fear, shame and guilt. This can occasionally cause severe cardiac harm, even death, but those are not strictly intended, and in the case of torture accidental death would even defeat the purpose.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Psychological punishments that are particularly cruel or severe may be considered [[psychological torture]].
Very common is the use of shame through private or, especially, [[public humiliation]].
For example, publicly shaving a woman’s head may not only humiliate her in front of those who witness her shearing, it may also deprive her of her hair for as long as it takes to grow back, thus serving as a continual reminder of her punishment and her humiliation.
==See also== *[[Punishment (Psychology)]] *[[Parading on donkey]] *[[Sluggishly progressing schizophrenia]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Psychological Punishment}} [[Category:Punishments]]

The '''Reprringer''' is a 3D printed [[pepperbox]] firearm,<ref name=5gunrefs>[http://3dprint.com/14636/3d-prnted-guns/ 5 Different 3D Printed Gun Models Have Been Fired Since May, 2013 – Here They Are], 3D Print, September 10, 2014. ([https://www.webcitation.org/6SVllm7Dl archive])</ref><ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013">[http://www.guns.com/2013/09/13/introducing-3d-printed-reprringer-pepperbox-video/ Introducing the 3D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox (VIDEO)], guns.com, September 13, 2013. ([https://www.webcitation.org/6SRc8adlR archive])</ref><ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/><ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/><ref name="3D Printed Pepperbox Pistol">[http://www.thefirearmblog.com/blog/2013/10/08/3d-printed-pepperbox-pistol/ 3D Printed Pepperbox Pistol], firearmblog, October 8, 2013. ([https://www.webcitation.org/6SRcXdCdQ archive])</ref><ref name="wired.co.uk">[https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-05/16/3d-printed-guns 3D printed guns a year on: from prototype to serious weapons], Wired, 16 May 2014. ([https://www.webcitation.org/6SRXdTEJs archive])</ref> made public around September 2013.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/> It was created by Hexen.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/><ref name="3D Printed Pepperbox Pistol"/> It can hold 5 cartridges and is chambered in .22 Caliber caps.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/><ref name="3D Printed Pepperbox Pistol"/>
==Development== It is an offspring of the [[RepRap]],{{fact|date=October 2014}} the open-source self-replicating 3D printer project, and derringer, the Reprringer is a 5-shot, single-action, manually-indexed 6mm Flobert [[pistol]] developed by Hexen.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/>
==Design== Unlike the many early 3D-printed firearm designs, which are usually massively overbuilt in order to withstand the pressures and strain on the material from modern gunpowder cartridges, the Reprringer is small and only slightly larger than a gun made from steel.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/> Two factors contribute to its small stature. First reason is that it is chambered for what is considered the least powerful commercially-produced cartridge on the market.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/>
According to Guns.com the ".22 CB aka 6mm Flobert is made from a cut-down .22 rimfire case loaded with just a primer or the primer and very little powder and a lightweight bullet". This makes the cartridge roughly on par with some [[air rifle]]s in terms of muzzle energy. This therefore means that the Reprringer does not require as much barrel. The design is improved over early completely 3D-printed guns as it uses unrifled steel inserts in the cylinder. This makes the gun safer and more reliable, it also provides a more consistent seal around the projectile; the all-polymer barrels have the ability to flex, thus letting much of the propellant escape, and are inefficient.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/>
Although the barrels are not rifled, the lack of theoretical accuracy therefrom is considered a relative non-issue in a small gun with no sights.<ref name="D-printed Reprringer Pepperbox 2013"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Richard J. Bolles | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1843|08|01}} | birth_place = | death_date = 1917<!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Land salesman | known_for = 1900s Florida land sale scam }} '''Richard "Dicky" J. Bolles''' was one of [[Florida]]'s many early land [[salesmen]]. He was also one of the first to market the land in small tracts to would be future residents. Born on August 1, 1843, in 1908 Bolles purchased {{convert|500000|acre|km2}} of undeveloped land from the state of Florida at the price of two dollars an [[acre]]. He went on to sell this land, sight unseen to unknowing non-residents. His salesmanship was ultimately a scam and in 1911 those who were caught up in it brought [[lawsuit|suit]] against him. Later in 1913 he was indicted and arrested, though later found innocent. Bolles died in 1917.
==References== * http://everglades.fiu.edu/reclaim/bios/bolles.htm * ''Up for Grabs'', John Rothchild, 1985

{{Other people}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox MP | name = Robert Maxwell | image = Robert_Maxwell_1989.jpg | imagesize = | caption =Robert Maxwell (1989) | constituency_MP = [[Buckingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Buckingham]] | parliament = | term_start = 15 October 1964 | term_end = 18 June 1970 | majority = | predecessor = [[Frank Markham]] | successor = [[William Benyon]] | birthname = Ján Ludvík Hyman Binyamin Hoch | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1923|6|10}} | birth_place = Slatinské Doly, [[First Czechoslovak Republic|Czechoslovakia]] (now [[Solotvyno]], [[Ukraine]]) | death_date = {{death date|df=yes|1991|11|5}} (aged 68) | death_place = Sea around [[Canary Islands]] | resting_place = [[Mount of Olives Jewish Cemetery]], [[Jerusalem]] | citizenship = Czechoslovak (1923-1946)
[[British nationality law|British]] (1946-1991) | party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | occupation = [[Publisher]], [[media proprietor]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Elisabeth Maxwell|Elisabeth Meynard]]|1946}} | children = {{ubl|Michael (1946-1967)|Philip (b. 1948)|Ann (b. 1949)|[[Christine Maxwell|Christine]] (b. 1951)|[[Isabel Maxwell|Isabel]] (b. 1951)|Karine (1954-1957)|[[Ian Maxwell|Ian]] (b. 1956)|[[Kevin Maxwell|Kevin]] (b. 1959)|[[Ghislaine Maxwell|Ghislaine]] (b. 1961)}}{{Cite book|last=Haines|first=Joe | authorlink=Joe Haines (journalist)| title=Maxwell | year=1988 | publisher=Futura | location=London | isbn=0-7088-4303-4 | pages=434 et seq}} | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | rank = [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|Captain]] | awards = [[File:Military Cross ribbon.png|30px]] [[Military Cross]] }} }} '''Ian Robert Maxwell''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|MC}} (10 June 1923 – 5 November 1991), born '''Ján Ludvík Hyman Binyamin Hoch''', was a British [[media proprietor]] and [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Member of Parliament]] (MP). Originally from [[Czechoslovakia]], Maxwell rose from poverty to build an extensive [[publishing]] empire. After his death, huge discrepancies in his companies' finances were revealed, including his [[fraud]]ulent misappropriation of the [[Mirror Group]] [[pension fund]].{{cite web|title=A Notorious Fraud – the Robert Maxwell Farrago|url=http://australian-guardians.org/?page_id=808|publisher=Australian Guardians|accessdate=12 December 2017}}{{cite web|title=The way is still clear for a tyrant and a fraud|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/the-way-is-still-clear-for-a-tyrant-and-a-fraud-1324867.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=12 December 2017|date=20 January 1996}} Early in his life, Maxwell escaped from [[Nazi occupation]], joined the [[Czechoslovak Army]] in exile in [[World War II]] and was decorated after active service in the [[British Army]]. In subsequent years he worked in publishing, building up [[Pergamon Press]] to a major publishing house. After six years as an MP during the 1960s, he again put all his energy into business, successively buying the [[British Printing Corporation]], [[Mirror Group Newspapers]] and [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Publishers]], among other publishing companies. Maxwell had a flamboyant lifestyle, living in [[Headington Hill Hall]] in [[Oxford]], from which he often flew in his helicopter, and sailing in his luxury yacht, the ''[[Lady Mona K|Lady Ghislaine]]''. He was notably litigious and often embroiled in controversy, including about his support for [[Israel]] at the time of the [[1948 Palestine war]]. In 1989, he had to sell successful businesses, including Pergamon Press, to cover some of his debts. In 1991, his body was discovered floating in the [[Atlantic Ocean]], having fallen overboard from his yacht. He was buried in [[Jerusalem]]. Maxwell's death triggered the collapse of his publishing empire as banks called in loans. His sons briefly attempted to keep the business together, but failed as the news emerged that the elder Maxwell had stolen hundreds of millions of pounds from his own companies' pension funds. The Maxwell companies applied for [[bankruptcy]] protection in 1992. ==Early life== Maxwell was born into a poor [[Yiddish]]-speaking [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[Jew]]ish family in the small town of Slatinské Doly (now [[Solotvyno]], [[Ukraine]]) in the easternmost province of pre-[[World War II]] [[Czechoslovakia]].Марк Штейнберг. Евреи в войнах тысячелетий. p. 227. {{ISBN|5-93273-154-0}} {{ru icon}}{{cite journal|author=Иван Мащенко|date=7–13 September 2002|script-title=ru:Медиа-олигарх из Солотвина|trans_title=|journal=Зеркало недели|issue=#34 (409)|url=http://www.zn.ua/3000/3760/35999/|language=Russian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121222202133/http://zn.ua/SOCIETY/media-oligarh_iz_solotvina-29458.html|archivedate=22 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Whitney|first=Craig R.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world/robert-maxwell-68-from-refugee-to-the-ruthless-builder-of-a-publishing-empire.html|title=Robert Maxwell, 68: From Refugee to the Ruthless Builder of a Publishing Empire|work=The New York Times|date=6 November 1991|page=5}} His parents were Mechel Hoch and Hannah Slomowitz. He had six siblings. In 1939, the area was reclaimed by [[Hungary]]. Most members of his family died in [[Auschwitz]] after Hungary was occupied in 1944 by [[Nazi Germany]], but he had already escaped to [[France]]. In [[Marseille]], he joined the [[Czechoslovak Army]] in exile in May 1940.[http://www.vuapraha.cz/Pages/DatabazeVHA/DetailVojaka.aspx?soldierId=64095 Ludvík Hoch (Maxwell) in the database of Central Military Archive in Prague] After the [[Battle of France|defeat in France]] and the retreat to [[Great Britain]], Maxwell (using the name "Ivan du Maurier" {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rwOCvfd6Ud4C&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=%22ivan+du+maurier%22&source=bl&ots=5gwXSXm0LF&sig=-6I4xzs0sE-h42qK2kwDDK6UqYQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Y2l1Vcb2OsqhsAGZjYC4CA&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22ivan%20du%20maurier%22&f=false|title=Naughty Boys: Ten Rogues of Oxford|work=google.se|accessdate=5 July 2015}}) took part in a protest against the leadership of the Czechoslovak Army, and with 500 other soldiers he was transferred to the [[Royal Pioneer Corps]] and later to the [[North Staffordshire Regiment]] in 1943. He was then involved in action across [[Europe]], from the [[Operation Overlord|Normandy beaches]] to [[Berlin]], and achieved the rank of [[Sergeant#United Kingdom|sergeant]]. He gained a commission in 1945 and was promoted to the rank of [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]]. In January 1945, he received the [[Military Cross]] from [[Bernard Montgomery|Field Marshal Montgomery]]. Attached to the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Foreign Office]], he served in Berlin during the next two years in the press section. Maxwell naturalised as a British subject on 19 June 1946{{London Gazette |issue=37658 |date=19 July 1946 |page=3739}} and legally changed his name by [[deed of change of name]] on 30 June 1948.{{London Gazette |issue=38352 |date=13 July 1948 |page=4046}} In 1945, he married [[Elisabeth Maxwell|Elisabeth "Betty" Meynard]], a [[French people|French]] [[Protestant]] with whom he had nine children with the goal of "recreating the family he lost in the [[Holocaust]]".{{cite news|last=Witchell|first=Alex|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE1DD103BF936A25751C0A963958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Interview with Elisabeth Maxwell |work=The New York Times |date=15 February 1995 |accessdate=31 October 2013}} Five of his children were later employed within his companies. His three-year-old daughter, Karine, died of [[leukemia]] and his eldest son, Michael, was severely injured in a car crash in 1961 (at the age of fifteen) while being driven home from a post-Christmas party when his driver fell asleep at the wheel. Michael never regained consciousness and died seven years later.Maxwell: The final verdict''A mind of my own'' by Elisabeth Maxwell{{cite web |url=http://www.free-researchpapers.com/dbs/a5/bmu335.shtml |title=Free Research Papers – Information Intelligence, 1991 |publisher=free-researchpapers.com |date=28 March 1999 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103051312/http://www.free-researchpapers.com/dbs/a5/bmu335.shtml |archivedate=3 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|last=Rampton|first=James|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/3664778/Maxwell-was-a-monster-but-much-more-too.html|title='Maxwell was a monster - but much more, too'|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 April 2007|accessdate=9 February 2018}} After World War II, Maxwell used various contacts in the [[Allied-occupied Germany|Allied occupation]] authorities to go into business, becoming the British and U.S. distributor for [[Springer Verlag]], a publisher of scientific books. In 1951, he bought three-quarters of Butterworth-Springer, a minor publisher; the remaining quarter was held by the experienced scientific editor [[Paul Rosbaud]].Haines (1988) 135 They changed the name of the company to [[Pergamon Press]] and rapidly built it into a major publishing house. In 1964, representing the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], Maxwell was elected as [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Buckingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Buckingham]] and re-elected in 1966. He gave an interview to ''[[The Times]]'' in 1968, in which he said the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] provided him with a problem. "I can't get on with men", he commented. "I tried having male assistants at first. But it didn't work. They tend to be too independent. Men like to have individuality. Women can become an extension of the boss."{{cite news|last=Barwick|first=Sandra|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-beast-and-his-beauties-robert-maxwell-mesmerised-and-bullied-women-but-betty-his-wife-for-nearly-50-years-remained-loyal-her-autobiography-will-be-her-first-public-breach-of-that-loyalty-sandra-barwick-reports-1444890.html|title=The beast and his beauties|work=The Independent|date=25 October 1994}} Maxwell lost his seat in 1970 to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[William Benyon]]. He contested Buckingham again in both 1974 general elections, but without success. At the beginning of 1969, it emerged that Maxwell's attempt to buy the ''[[News of the World]]'' had failed.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/2/newsid_2492000/2492157.stm|title=1969: Murdoch wins Fleet Street foothold|work=BBC'' On this Day 2 January}} The Carr family, which owned the title, was incensed at the thought of a Czech immigrant with [[socialist]] politics gaining ownership and the board voted against Maxwell's bid without any dissent. The ''News of the World''{{'}}s editor [[Stafford Somerfield]] opposed Maxwell's bid in an October 1968 front page opinion piece, in which he referred to Maxwell's Czech origins and used his birth name.{{cite book|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KPR0pB9UCS4C&pg=PA213|title=Press Gang: How Newspapers Make Profits From Propaganda|location=London|publisher=Pan|year=2004|orig-year=2003|page=395}} He wrote, "This is a British paper, run by British people...as British as roast beef and [[Yorkshire pudding]]...Let us keep it that way".{{cite news|last=Grundy|first=Bill|url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/25th-october-1968/6/mr-maxwell-and-the-ailing-giant|title=Mr Maxwell and the Ailing Giant|work=The Spectator|date=24 October 1968|page=6}} The tycoon who gained control was the [[Australia]]n [[Rupert Murdoch]], who later that year acquired ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', which had also previously interested Maxwell.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15576907|title=The Maxwell Murdoch tabloid rivalry|work=BBC News|date=5 November 2011}} ==Pergamon lost and regained== In 1969, [[Saul Steinberg (business)|Saul Steinberg]], head of "Leasco Data Processing Corporation", was interested in a strategic acquisition of Pergamon. Steinberg claimed that during negotiations, Maxwell falsely stated that a subsidiary responsible for publishing [[encyclopedia]]s was extremely profitable.Dennis Barker and Christopher Sylvester [http://politics.guardian.co.uk/politicsobituaries/story/0,1441,587914,00.html "The grasshopper",] – Obituary of Maxwell, ''The Guardian'', 6 November 1991. Retrieved on 19 July 2007.Nicholas Davenport [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/30th-august-1969/24/money-wanted-a-board-of-trade-inquiry "Money Wanted: A Board of Trade inquiry"], ''The Spectator'', 29 August 1969, p.24 At the same time, Pergamon had been forced to reduce its profit forecasts for 1969 from £2.5 million to £2.05 million during the period of negotiations, and dealing in Pergamon shares was suspended on the [[London stock exchange|London stock markets]]. This caused Maxwell to lose control of Pergamon and he was expelled from the board in October 1969, along with three other directors in sympathy with him, by the majority owners of the company's shares.Nicholas Davenport [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/18th-october-1969/22/money "Money: The End of the Affair"], ''The Spectator'', 17 October 1969, p.22 Steinberg purchased Pergamon. An inquiry by the [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] (DTI) under the Takeover Code of the time reported in mid-1971: "We regret having to conclude that, notwithstanding Mr Maxwell's acknowledged abilities and energy, he is not in our opinion a person who can be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company." It was found that Maxwell had contrived to maximise Pergamon's share price through transactions between his private family companies. At the same time, the [[United States Congress]] was investigating Leasco's takeover practices. Justice [[Thayne Forbes]] in September 1971 was critical of the inquiry: "They had moved from an inquisitorial role to accusatory one and virtually committed the business murder of Mr. Maxwell." He further continued that the trial judge would probably find that the inspectors had acted "contrary to the rules of natural justice".Betty Maxwell, p. 542 The company performed poorly under Steinberg; Maxwell reacquired Pergamon in 1974 after borrowing funds.[https://web.archive.org/web/20020818222600/http://www.ketupa.net/maxwell.htm "Robert Maxwell: Overview"], keputa.net Maxwell established the Maxwell Foundation in [[Liechtenstein]] in 1970. He acquired the British Printing Corporation (BPC) in 1981 and changed its name first to the British Printing and Communication Corporation (BPCC) and then to the [[Maxwell Communications Corporation]]. The company was later sold in a [[management buyout]] and is now known as Polestar. ==Later business activities== In July 1984, Maxwell acquired [[Mirror Group Newspapers]] from [[Reed International]] plc.[https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/14/world/briton-buys-the-mirror-chain.html "Briton Buys the Mirror Chain"], ''The New York Times'', 14 July 1984 for £113 million.Roy Greenslade [https://books.google.com/books?id=KPR0pB9UCS4C&pg=PA395 ''Press Gang: How Newspapers Make Profits From Propaganda''], London: Pan, 2004 [2003], p.395 MGN, now part of [[Reach plc]], formerly Trinity Mirror, published the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', a pro-Labour [[tabloid journalism|tabloid]], and other popular newspapers in [[England]] and [[Scotland]]. At a press conference to publicise his acquisition, Maxwell said his editors would be "free to produce the news without interference". Meanwhile, at a meeting of Maxwell's new employees, ''Mirror'' journalist [[Joe Haines (journalist)|Joe Haines]] asserted that he was able to prove that their boss "is a crook and a liar".[http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/22nd-february-1992/15/say-it-aint-so-joe "Say It Ain't So, Joe"], ''The Spectator'', 22 February 1992, p.15Roy Greenslade [https://books.google.com/books?id=KPR0pB9UCS4C&pg=PA395 ''Press Gang''], p.395 Haines quickly came under Maxwell's influence and later wrote his authorised biography. In June 1985, Maxwell announced a takeover of [[Clive Sinclair|Sir Clive Sinclair's]] ailing [[home computer]] company, [[Sinclair Research]], through Hollis Brothers, a Pergamon Press subsidiary.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/18/business/sinclair-to-sell-british-unit.html|title=Sinclair to Sell British Unit|date=18 June 1985|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=4 December 2009}} The deal was aborted in August 1985.{{cite web|url=http://www.nvg.ntnu.no/sinclair/sinclair/corphist.htm|title=Sinclair: A Corporate History|work=Planet Sinclair|accessdate=4 December 2009}} In 1987, Maxwell purchased part of [[IPC Media]] to create [[Fleetway Publications]]. That same year, he launched the ''[[London Daily News]]'' in February after a delay caused by production problems, but the paper closed in July after sustaining significant losses contemporary estimates put at £25 million.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19870725&id=HkJAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TFkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3086,5817873 "Maxwell Closes London Paper"], ''Glasgow Herald'', 25 July 1987, p.3 At first intended to be a rival to the ''[[London Evening Standard|Evening Standard]]'', Maxwell had made a rash decision for it to be the first 24-hour paper as well.Duncan Campbell [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/aug/28/mondaymediasection.pressandpublishing1 "The London legacy of Cap'n Bob"], ''The Guardian'', 28 August 2006 By 1988, Maxwell's various companies owned, in addition to the Mirror titles and Pergamon Press, [[Nimbus Records]], [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Publishers]] (of which Collier was a part), Maxwell Directories, [[Prentice Hall]] Information Services and the [[Berlitz International|Berlitz language schools]]. He also owned a half-share of [[MTV]] in Europe and other European [[television]] interests, Maxwell Cable TV and Maxwell Entertainment. Maxwell purchased Macmillan, the American publishing firm, during 1988 for $2.6 billion. In the same year, he launched an ambitious new project, a transnational newspaper called ''[[The European (newspaper)|The European]]''. In 1991, he was forced to sell Pergamon Press and Maxwell Directories to [[Elsevier]] for £440 million to cover his debts; he used some of this money to buy an ailing tabloid, the [[New York City|New York]] ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''. Also in 1991, Maxwell sold 49 percent of the stock of Mirror Group Newspapers to the public. Maxwell's links with [[Eastern Europe]]an [[totalitarian]] regimes resulted in several biographies (generally considered to be [[Hagiography#Secular usage|hagiographies]]David Ellis and Sidney Urquhart [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,972683,00.html "Maxwell's Hall of Shame"], ''Time'', 8 April 1991) of those countries' leaders, with interviews conducted by Maxwell, for which he received much derision. At the beginning of an interview with [[Romania]]'s [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]], then the country's [[Communist]] leader, he asked, "How do you account for your enormous popularity with the Romanian people?"[http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/21st-december-1991/3/-41- Editorial: "Breaking the Spell"], ''The Spectator'', 21 December 1991, p.3 [[File:Oxford brookes headington hill.JPG|thumb|For the last 32 years of his life, Robert Maxwell lived at [[Headington Hill Hall]], which he rented from [[Oxford City Council]] and described as "the best [[council house]]" in the country.[http://www.headington.org.uk/history/famous_people/maxwell.htm ""], Headington History It is now part of [[Oxford Brookes University]].]] Maxwell was also the chairman of [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], saving them from [[bankruptcy]] and attempting to merge them with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in 1983 to form a club he wished to call "[[Thames Valley Royals proposal|Thames Valley Royals]]". He took Oxford into the top flight of English football in 1985 and the team won the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] a year later. Maxwell bought into [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in 1987. He also attempted to buy [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 1984, but refused owner [[Martin Edwards]]'s asking price. Maxwell was known to be litigious against those who would speak or write against him. The satirical magazine ''[[Private Eye]]'' lampooned him as "Cap'n Bob" and the "bouncing Czech",Jon Kelly [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6620291.stm "The strange allure of Robert Maxwell"], BBC News, 4 May 2007 the latter nickname having originally been devised by [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Harold Wilson]]Reuters [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-01/news/sns-rt-newscorp-hackingmaxwelll5e8g18z9-20120501_1_lady-ghislaine-maxwell-companies-british-parliamentary-committee "Murdoch conclusion stirs memories of his old foe Maxwell"], ''Chicago Tribune'', 1 May 2012 (under whom Maxwell was an MP). Maxwell took out several [[libel]] actions against ''Private Eye'', one resulting in the magazine losing an estimated £225,000 and Maxwell using his commercial power to hit back with a one-off spoof magazine ''[[Not Private Eye]]''.[http://www.magforum.com/notprivateeye.htm "Not Private Eye"], Tony Quinn, ''Magforum.com'', 6 March 2007 ==Israeli connection== ===1948 war=== A hint of Maxwell's service to the [[Israel]]i state was provided by [[John Loftus (author)|John Loftus]] and [[Mark Aarons]], who described Maxwell's contacts with Czechoslovak anti-Stalinist Communist leaders in 1948 as crucial to the Czechoslovak decision to arm Israel in the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]]. Czechoslovak military assistance was both unique and crucial for the fledgling state as it battled for its existence. It was Maxwell's covert help in smuggling aircraft parts into Israel that led to the country having air supremacy during their [[1948 Palestine war|1948 War of Independence]].[[John Loftus (author)|John Loftus]] and [[Mark Aarons]], ''The Secret War Against the Jews''. ===Mossad allegations; Vanunu case=== Shortly before Maxwell's death, a former employee of Israel's [[Military Intelligence Directorate (Israel)|Military Intelligence Directorate]], [[Ari Ben-Menashe]], approached a number of news organisations in Britain and the U.S. with the allegation that Maxwell and the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''{{'}}s foreign editor, [[Nicholas Davies (journalist)|Nicholas Davies]], were both long-time agents for [[Mossad]]. Ben-Menashe also claimed that in 1986, Maxwell had told the [[Embassy of Israel, London|Israeli Embassy in London]] that [[Mordechai Vanunu]] had given information about [[Israel's nuclear capability]] to ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]]'', then to the ''Daily Mirror''. Vanunu was subsequently [[kidnap]]ped by Mossad and smuggled to Israel, convicted of [[treason]] and imprisoned for eighteen years. Ben-Menashe's story was ignored at first, but eventually ''[[The New Yorker]]'' journalist [[Seymour Hersh]] repeated some of the allegations during a press conference in London held to publicise ''[[The Samson Option: Israel's Nuclear Arsenal and American Foreign Policy|The Samson Option]]'', Hersh's book about Israel's nuclear weapons. On 21 October 1991, two MPs, [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]'s [[George Galloway]] and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative's]] [[Rupert Allason]] (also known as espionage author Nigel West), agreed to raise the issue in the House of Commons under [[Parliamentary Privilege]] protection,which allows MPs to ask questions in Parliament without risk of being sued for defamation. which in turn allowed British newspapers to report events without fear of libel suits. Maxwell called the claims "ludicrous, a total invention" and sacked Davies. A year later, in Galloway's libel settlement against Mirror Group Newspapers (in which he received "substantial" damages), Galloway's counsel announced that the MP accepted that the group's staff had not been involved in Vanunu's abduction. Galloway himself, however, referred to Maxwell as "one of the worst criminals of the century."[http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/scottish-mp-wins-libel-damages-1.779636 "Scottish MP wins libel damages"], ''The Herald'' (Glasgow), 22 December 1992 ==Death== On 5 November 1991, Maxwell was last in contact with the crew of his [[yacht]], the ''[[Lady Mona K|Lady Ghislaine]]'', at 4:25 a.m. local time, but was found to be missing later in the morning.Ben Laurance and John Hooper, et al [https://www.theguardian.com/fromthearchive/story/0,,1078193,00.html "Maxwell's body found in sea"], ''The Guardian'', 6 November 1991 Maxwell was presumed to have fallen overboard from the vessel, which was cruising off the [[Canary Islands]],{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/1249739.stm|title=Robert Maxwell: A Profile|publisher=BBC News|date=29 March 2001|accessdate=4 April 2009}} and his naked body was subsequently recovered from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].Robert Verkaik [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/the-mystery-of-maxwells-death-469294.html "The Mystery of Maxwell's Death"], ''The Independent'', 10 March 2006 The official ruling at an inquest held in December 1991 was death by a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] combined with accidental [[drowning]],Larry Eichel [http://articles.philly.com/1991-12-14/news/25810731_1_lady-ghislaine-insurers-tycoon "Maxwell's Legacy Of Money Troubles Maxwell's Own ''Daily Mirror'' Newspaper Now Routinely Calls Him 'The Cheating Tycoon'"], ''Philadelphia Inquirer'', 14 December 1991 although three pathologists had been unable to agree on the cause of his death at the inquest; he had been found to have been suffering from serious heart and lung conditions.Marlise Simons [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/business/autopsy-indicates-maxwell-did-not-drown.html "Autopsy Indicates Maxwell Did Not Drown"], ''The New York Times'', 12 December 1991 Murder was ruled out by the judge and, in effect, so was suicide. He was buried on the [[Mount of Olives]] in [[Jerusalem]].Clyde Haberman [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/business/the-media-business-maxwell-is-buried-in-jerusalem.html "The Media Business; Maxwell Is Buried In Jerusalem"], ''The New York Times'', 11 November 1991 Prime Minister [[John Major]] said Maxwell had given him "valuable insights" into the situation in the [[Soviet Union]] during the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|attempted coup of 1991]]. He was a "great character", Major added. [[Neil Kinnock]], then Labour Party leader, spoke of him as a man with "a zest for life" who "attracted controversy, envy and loyalty in great measure throughout his rumbustious life." A production crew conducting research for ''[[Maxwell (film)|Maxwell]]'', an eponymous biographical film by the [[BBC]], uncovered tapes stored in a suitcase owned by his former head of security, John Pole. Later in his life, Maxwell had become increasingly paranoid of his own employees and had the offices of those he suspected of disloyalty [[Covert listening device|wired]] so he could hear their conversations. After Maxwell's death, the tapes remained in Pole's suitcase and were only discovered by the researchers in 2007.{{cite news|title=BBC reveals secret Maxwell tapes|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6590755.stm|publisher=BBC|date=25 April 2007}} ==Aftermath: Theft of pension funds, collapse of a publishing empire== {{refimprove|section|date=June 2017}} Maxwell's death triggered a flood of instability, with banks frantically calling in their massive loans. His sons, [[Kevin Maxwell|Kevin]] and [[Ian Maxwell|Ian]], struggled to hold the empire together, but were unable to prevent its collapse. It emerged that without adequate prior authorisation, Maxwell had used hundreds of millions of pounds from his companies' [[pension fund]]s to shore up the shares of the Mirror Group to save his companies from bankruptcy.{{cite news|last1=Prokesch|first1=Steven|title=Maxwell's Mirror Group Has $727.5 Million Loss|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/24/business/maxwell-s-mirror-group-has-727.5-million-loss.html|accessdate=9 February 2018|work=The New York Times|date=24 June 1992}} Eventually, the pension funds were replenished with monies from [[investment bank]]s [[Shearson Lehman]] and [[Goldman Sachs]], as well as the British government. This replenishment was limited and also supported by a surplus in the printers' fund, which was taken by the government in part payment of £100 million required to support the workers' state pensions. The rest of the £100 million was waived. Maxwell's theft of pension funds was therefore partly repaid from public funds. The result was that in general pensioners received about 50 percent of their company pension entitlement. The Maxwell companies filed for bankruptcy protection in 1992. Kevin Maxwell was declared bankrupt with debts of £400 million. In 1995, Kevin and Ian and two other former directors went on trial for conspiracy to defraud, but were unanimously [[acquittal|acquitted]] by a twelve-man jury in 1996. In November 1994, Maxwell's widow, Elisabeth, published her memoirs, ''A Mind of My Own: My Life with Robert Maxwell'',{{cite web |url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v17/n02/jenny-diski/bob-and-betty |title=Bob and Betty |last=Diski |first=Jenny |authorlink=Jenny Diski|date=26 January 1995|website=[[London Review of Books]]|accessdate=16 December 2014}} which sheds light on her life with Maxwell, when the publishing magnate was ranked as one of the richest individuals in the world.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE6D81139F932A35752C0A963958260 | work=The New York Times | title=A Match for Robert Maxwell | first=Ben | last=MacIntyre | date=1 January 1995 | accessdate=22 May 2010}} She devoted much of her life to researching the Holocaust and to Judeo-Christian dialogue. She died on 7 August 2013.Roy Greenslade, "[https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2013/aug/09/daily-mirror-holocaust Betty, Robert Maxwell's widow, dies aged 92]", ''[[The Guardian]]'' (9 '''SS ''Calabria''''' was a passenger and cargo steamship. [[AG Weser]] built her for [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]]. She was launched as '''D/S ''Werra''''' and completed in 1922. ("D/S" stands for ''Dampfschiff'' in German as "SS" stands for "steamship" in English.)
In 1935 she was bought by [[Italian Line|Flotte Riunite Cosulich-Lloyd-Sabaudo Navigazione Generale]], who renamed her '''''Calabria'''''. In 1937 she was sold to [[Italia Marittima|Lloyd Triestino]].
In June 1940 the UK seized her and placed in the management of the [[British-India Steam Navigation Company]]. In December 1940 she was torpedoed and sunk. When she sank, all of her 360 passengers and crew lost their lives. The [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) was going to rename her '''''Empire Inventor''''', but she was sunk before this had been done.
==Building and career== The [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]] seized numerous NDL ships either during the First World War as [[Prize (law)|prize ships]] or afterwards for [[World War I reparations|war reparations]]. In the 1920s NDL replaced them with a new fleet from [[Bremer Vulkan]], [[AG Vulcan Stettin]] and AG Weser. The first of the new ships were delivered in 1922; ''Werra'' among them.
''Werra'' was one of a series of six [[sister ship]]s that AG Weser built for NDL. ''Werra'' and {{SS|Weser|1922|2}} were completed in 1922;<ref name=LR33/> {{SS|Coblenz|1923|2}}, {{SS|Saarbrücken|1923|2}} and {{SS|Trier|1923|2}} in 1923<ref name=LR-Sicilia> {{cite book |url = http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0800.pdf |year = 1937 |title = Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motorships |location = London |publisher = [[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref name=LR-Toscana> {{cite book |url = http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0886.pdf |year = 1937 |title = Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motorships |location = London |publisher = [[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref> {{cite book |url = http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b1219.pdf |year = 1930 |title = Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motor Ships |location = London |publisher = [[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> and {{SS|Fulda|1924|2}} in 1924.<ref> {{cite book |url = http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0438.pdf |year = 1930 |title = Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motor Ships |location = London |publisher = [[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref>
''Werra'' had two three-cylinder [[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|triple-expansion steam engines]] and twin [[Propeller (marine)|screws]].<ref name=LR33/> Between them her two engines were rated at 604 [[Horsepower#Nominal horsepower|NHP]].<ref name=LR33/> ''Werra'' was equipped with wireless [[direction finding]] and submarine signalling.<ref name=LR33/>
In 1935 NDL sold ''Werra'', ''Coblenz'' and ''Saarbrücken'' to Flotte Riunite Cosulich-Lloyd-Sabaudo which renamed them ''Calabria'', ''Sicilia'' and ''Toscana'' and registered them in [[Port of Genoa|Genoa]].<ref name=LR36/><ref name=LR-Sicilia/><ref name=LR-Toscana/> In 1937 the three ships were sold to [[Italia Marittima|Lloyd Triestino]],<ref name=LR-Sicilia/><ref name=LR-Toscana/> which registered ''Calabria'' in [[Port of Trieste|Trieste]].<ref name=LR37/>
On 10 June 1940 Italy declared war on France and the United Kingdom. At the time ''Calabria'' was in drydock in [[Port of Kolkata|Calcutta]] in [[British Raj|British India]], so on 11 June the British authorities seized her.<ref name=Uboat/> She was transferred to the MoWT, which appointed the [[British-India Steam Navigation Company]] to manage her.<ref name=Uboat/> The MoWT planned to rename her ''[[Empire ship|Empire]] Inventor'', but this intention was overtaken by events.<ref name=Uboat/>
==Sinking== {{location map |North Atlantic |width = 304 |lat = 52.43 |long = -18.07 |caption = Approximate position of ''Calabria''{{'}}s wreck in the [[Western Approaches]] |relief = yes }} In December 1940 ''Calabria'' was ''en route'' to the UK with a cargo of 4,000 tons of iron, 3,050 tons of tea and 1,870 tons of [[oilcake]]. Her [[Sea captain|Master]], David Lonie, commanded 128 officers and crew plus one [[Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships|DEMS]] gunner.<ref name=Uboat/> She was also carrying 230 mostly Indian supernumaries who were travelling to crew other ships.<ref name=Uboat/> Calabria{{'}}s crew and supernumaries included also four [[Hong Kong people|Hong Kong Chinese]] crewmen<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/a.htm |last = Taylor |first = Ron |title = Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – A |work = Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/l.htm |last = Taylor |first = Ron |title = Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – L |work = Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/t.htm |last = Taylor |first = Ron |title = Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – T |work = Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref name=Crew> {{cite web |url = http://uboat.net/allies/merchants/crews/ship710.html |title = Calabria |work = Crew lists from ships hit by U-boats |last = Helgason |first = Guðmundur |date = 1995–2013 |publisher = Guðmundur Helgason |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> and one Danish merchant officer.<ref name=Crew/>
''Calabria'' left [[Freetown]] in [[Sierra Leone]] with convoy [[List of World War II convoy codes#S|SLS]]-56 to the UK but fell behind.<ref name=Uboat/> On the evening of Sunday 8 December [[German Type IX submarine]] {{GS|U-103|1940|2}}, commanded by the [[Submarine aces|U-boat ace]] [[Viktor Schütze]], torpedoed her in the [[Western Approaches]] about {{convert|295|nmi|km}} west of [[Slyne Head lighthouse|Slyne Head]] in [[County Galway]], Ireland.<ref name=Uboat/> U-103 hit ''Calabria'' with one torpedo at 2058 hrs and a second at 2106 hrs.<ref name=Uboat/> All 360 hands and passengers were lost: there were no survivors.<ref name=Uboat/>
''Calabria''{{'}}s [[latitude]] was 52 degrees 26 minutes north, at that time of year the sun would have set just before 1600 hours local time, and the ship would have been [[Blackout (wartime)#World War II|blacked out]] under wartime regulations. However, [[Phases of the moon#Names of lunar phases|the moon was waxing gibbous]], had risen at 1315 hrs and did not set until 0218 hrs in the small hours of the next morning.<ref> {{cite news |url = http://aa.usno.navy.mil/cgi-bin/aa_pap.pl |author = US Naval Observatory Astronomical Applications Department |title = Sun and Moon Data for One Day |publisher = [[United States Navy]] |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> If the sky was clear, Schütze would have been able to target ''Calabria'' by moonlight.
The oldest man aboard was ''Calabria''{{'}}s chief cook, Santan Martins, who was 79 years old.<ref name=Crew/> Martins may have been the oldest merchant seaman killed at sea in the Second World War.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://ww2talk.com/forums/topic/15879-merchant-marine-deaths-ww2-the-oldest/ |author = Geoff501 |title = Merchant Marine Deaths WW2 - The Oldest? |publisher = WW2Talk |date = 29 June 2009 |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.militarian.com/threads/merchant-marine-deaths-ww2-the-oldest.5355/ |last = McGee |first = Billy |title = Merchant Marine Deaths WW2 - The Oldest? |publisher = Militarian Military History Forum |date = 30 June 2009 |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref>
==Monuments and relics== Those who died in ''Calabria''{{'}}s sinking are commemorated in the Second World War section of the [[Tower Hill Memorial|Merchant Navy War Memorial at Tower Hill]] in London.<ref name=ConvoyWeb> {{cite web |url = http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sl/mem/56_1.htm |last = McGee |first = Billy |title = MV Calabria (sic) |work = Convoy Web |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> Her Indian seamen and supernumaries are commemorated in the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]] monuments at [[Chittagong]] and [[Mumbai]].<ref name=ConvoyWeb/>
In 1940 after the British seized ''Calabria'' a small bronze [[ship's bell]] was removed from her.<ref name=Bonhams> {{cite web |url = http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/20765/lot/11/ |title = 11 A B ronze ship's bell, SS Calabria 1922 |publisher = [[Bonhams]] |date = 24 April 2013 |accessdate = 30 June 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> It was offered at auction in September 2012<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19925/lot/53A/ |title = 11 A Bronze ship's bell, SS Calabria 1922 |publisher = [[Bonhams]] |date = 26 September 2012 |accessdate = 1 July 2013 |ref = harv }}</ref> and again in April 2013.<ref name=Bonhams/>

[[File:Executioner.jpg|thumb]] The term '''Scharfrichter''' ([[German language|German]] for [[executioner]], literally: "sharp judge") refers specifically to a tradition of executioners in the German states. Using a [[Executioner's sword|sword of execution]], they had the responsibility of actually executing prisoners; his assistant, the "Löwe" (lion), would carry out tasks such as forcibly conveying prisoners to the presence of a [[judge]] (while roaring, whence the name), "rubbish clearance", burying unwanted bodies, and carrying out [[human branding|brandings]]. The Scharfrichter was a well-known figure nicknamed the "Mate of Death" and instantly recognizable in their traditional black [[frock coat]] and [[silk]] [[top hat]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Farrington |first=Karen |title=Dark Justice: A History of Punishment and Torture |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=2M5nPQAACAAJ |publisher=Smithmark |year=1996 |page=132 |isbn=0-7651-9910-6}}</ref>
The word "Scharfrichter" is composed of the words "scharf" (sharp/edged), and "Richter" (judge), because he had to do justice (richten) with the sword.
[[File:Praxis rerum criminalium iconibus illustrata. Antwerpen - Beller - 1562.jpg|thumb]]
==See also== *[[Scharfrichterhaus]] ==References== <references/>

'''Sexual maturity''' is the capability of an [[organism]] to [[reproduction|reproduce]]. It may be considered [[synonym]]ous with [[adulthood]],<ref name="McNamara">{{cite book|author=Thomas Edward McNamara| title =Evolution, Culture, and Consciousness: The Discovery of the Preconscious Mind| isbn = 076182765X | publisher = [[University Press of America]] | year = 2004 | page = 262-263|accessdate=March 20, 2018|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BeLmG7HP_U0C&pg=PA262}}</ref> but, in humans, [[puberty]] encompasses the process of sexual maturation and adulthood is based on cultural definitions.<ref name="McNamara"/><ref name="Sanfilippo">{{cite book|authors=Joseph S. Sanfilippo, Eduardo Lara-Torre, D. Keith Edmonds, Claire Templeman| title =Clinical Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology|isbn = 0203091787 | publisher = [[CRC Press]] | year = 2008 | page = 34|accessdate=March 20, 2018|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oM_KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT34|quote=The definition of puberty alone can encompass the process of sexual maturation, but a more expansive approach is to think of puberty in combination with the term adolescence. This differentiation prompts the practitioner to consider the psychological, behavioral, and social changes of the adolescent who is experiencing pubertal development.}}</ref>
Most [[multicellular]] organisms are unable to [[sexually reproduce]] at birth (or germination), and depending on the species, it may be days, weeks, or years until their bodies are able to do so. Also, certain cues may cause the organism to become sexually mature. They may be external, such as drought, or internal, such as percentage of body fat (such internal cues are not to be confused with hormones which directly produce sexual maturity).
Sexual maturity is brought about by a maturing of the reproductive organs and the production of [[gamete]]s. It may also be accompanied by a growth spurt or other physical changes which distinguish the immature organism from its adult form. These are termed [[secondary sex characteristic]]s, and often represent an increase in [[sexual dimorphism]]. For example, before puberty, human children have flat chests, but adult females have generally larger [[breast]]s than adult males. However, there are exceptions such as obesity and hormone imbalances such as [[gynecomastia]].
After sexual maturity is achieved, it is possible for some organisms to become [[infertile]], or even to [[Sex change|change their sex]]. Some organisms are [[hermaphrodite]]s and may or may not be able to produce viable offspring. Also, while in many organisms sexual maturity is strongly linked to age, many other factors are involved, and it is possible for some to display most or all of the characteristics of the adult form without being sexually mature. Conversely it is also possible for the "immature" form of an organism to reproduce. This is called ''progenesis'', in which sexual development occurs faster than other physiological development (in contrast, the term ''[[neoteny]]'' refers to when non-sexual development is slowed - but the result is the same, the retention of juvenile characteristics into adulthood). ==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[Gonadosomatic index]]
